intro: Phyteuma spicatum var. nigrum, commonly known as black evening primrose, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Onagraceae family and is characterized by its dark purple to black flowers that bloom in late summer. The plant has slender, branched stems and lance-shaped leaves that are hairy to the touch. Its flowers are typically arranged in spikes and are pollinated by insects, particularly moths and bees. The plant is often found in moist, open habitats such as meadows and woodland edges.
